C. Cloud bursting

Cloud bursting is a scalability model in which an organization uses its private cloud resources for normal day-to-day computing but relies on public cloud resources (cloud services) during periods of increased demand or resource requirements. In this scenario, the private cloud hosts the business applications, and the public cloud services are used for replication and to provide additional resources when needed, making it an example of cloud bursting to handle scalability requirements.

A developer wants to use an environment that has two sets of servers, with one active and one passive at any time. When a new version of the application is ready, it will be installed to the passive servers, which will then become active. Which of the following environment types BEST describes these two sets of servers?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Explanation:
A blue-green deployment is a deployment strategy that uses two identical environments, where:

Blue (active) serves live traffic.
Green (passive) is idle and used for staging the new version.
When a new version is ready:

It is deployed to the Green (passive) environment.
After testing, traffic is switched from Blue (old) to Green (new).
If issues arise, traffic can roll back to Blue.
This ensures zero downtime and reduces the risk of deployment failures.

Selected Answer: B
Explanation:
Containers are the best solution for isolation, portability, and scalability, because:

Isolation → Containers encapsulate applications with their dependencies, ensuring they run consistently across environments.
Portability → Containers run identically on any system that supports container runtimes (e.g., Docker, Kubernetes).
Scalability → Containers easily scale up/down based on demand, especially when orchestrated using Kubernetes.
